claim: It's always humid in Hong Kong.

supporting.text: Hong Kong has a subtropical climate with high humidity levels throughout much of the year.

attacks.text: Hong Kong has a subtropical climate with high humidity levels throughout much of the year.
Humidity levels in Hong Kong drop significantly during the winter months, making it less humid than other seasons.
Even in winter, Hong Kong's humidity remains relatively high compared to many temperate regions, maintaining a subtropical feel.
Urban areas in Hong Kong often experience lower humidity due to the heat island effect, contradicting the claim of 'always humid.'
The heat island effect may reduce relative humidity slightly, but absolute humidity remains high due to the coastal location.

supporting.text: Hong Kong experiences a monsoon season from May to September, which brings consistently high humidity.

attacks.text: Hong Kong experiences a monsoon season from May to September, which brings consistently high humidity.
From October to April, Hong Kong's humidity levels drop significantly due to the northeast monsoon, making it less humid for nearly half the year.
Even during the drier months, Hong Kong's proximity to the sea ensures that humidity levels remain relatively high compared to inland areas.
Inland areas of Hong Kong, such as the New Territories, can experience much lower humidity levels during the winter months, contradicting the notion of consistent humidity.

supporting.text: Coastal cities like Hong Kong generally have higher humidity due to proximity to large bodies of water.

attacks.text: Coastal cities like Hong Kong generally have higher humidity due to proximity to large bodies of water.
Hong Kong experiences dry seasons where humidity drops significantly, such as during winter months.
Even in dry seasons, Hong Kong's humidity remains higher than inland cities at similar latitudes due to maritime influence.
Urban heat island effects in Hong Kong can sometimes reduce relative humidity despite high absolute moisture levels.
The urban heat island primarily affects temperature, not absolute humidity, which remains consistently high from maritime air masses.

supporting.text: Winter months in Hong Kong can have lower humidity levels compared to the rest of the year.

attacks.text: Winter months in Hong Kong can have lower humidity levels compared to the rest of the year.
Even in winter, Hong Kong's humidity rarely drops below 60%, which is still considered humid by most standards.
60% humidity in winter is significantly lower than the 80-90% levels typical in summer, making winter relatively less humid.
The perception of humidity is subjective, and many people still find 60% humidity uncomfortable or humid.

supporting.text: Urban areas in Hong Kong can experience the urban heat island effect, which may contribute to higher humidity.

attacks.text: Urban areas in Hong Kong can experience the urban heat island effect, which may contribute to higher humidity.
The urban heat island effect primarily increases temperature, not necessarily humidity, as it reduces green spaces that contribute to moisture.
Even with reduced green spaces, urban areas can still retain humidity due to human activities like air conditioning and water usage.
Hong Kong's coastal location and monsoon climate are the primary drivers of humidity, not urban effects.

supporting.text: Hong Kong's humidity levels are influenced by seasonal wind patterns, which can vary throughout the year.

attacks.text: Hong Kong's humidity levels are influenced by seasonal wind patterns, which can vary throughout the year.
Despite seasonal variations, Hong Kong's average relative humidity remains consistently high, often above 70% year-round.
Even with high average humidity, there are dry periods in winter when humidity drops significantly, making the claim 'always humid' inaccurate.
The perception of humidity is also subjective; what feels humid to some may not to others, regardless of measured levels.
